paragraph.paragraph: EiffelEnvision attempts, at its best, to accommodate both existing EiffelStudio developers and EiffelEnvision developers at the same time. However, the two development environments are very disparate. Due to the integration into Visual Studio .NET, EiffelEnvision favors the Visual Studio .NET User Interface (UI) mechanisms ensuring consistency for Visual Studio .NET developers. EiffelStudio users should not feel at a loss when migrating to EiffelEnvision. EiffelEnvision extends the Visual Studio .NET base UI to provide extensions that are EiffelStudio-like and facilitate EiffelStudio users with features they are accustomed to using. The information detailed here is to start EiffelStudio users on the right track when getting started with EiffelEnvision. It is recommended that EiffelStudio users without prior knowledge of Visual Studio .NET review the vxconDevelopingApplicationsWithVisualStudio 0 Developing with Visual Studio .NET documentation before using EiffelEnvision.
paragraph.note: Note: EiffelEnvision is a complete language plug-in for Visual Studio .NET and does not repeat any documentation located in the Microsoft Visual Studio .NET documentation. Links to the Visual Studio .NET documentation are provided, in abundance, throughout the EiffelEnvision documentation. Any extensions to the Visual Studio .NET user interface or additional features not common to Visual Studio .NET are documented to the required degree for understanding.
Note: This section of the documentation assumes knowledge of EiffelStudio and Eiffel for .NET.
paragraph.paragraph: The following sections outline the major features differences of EiffelEnvision and Visual Studio .NET compared with EiffelStudio.

There are many differences in the UI of EiffelEnvision and Visual Studio .NET, compared to EiffelStudio. One of the biggest UI features missing is EiffelStudio's employment of a mechasim commonly referred to as Pick and Drop. Pick and Drop is specific to the EiffelVision 2 library, which EiffelStudio is built upon and Microsoft Visual Studio .NET is not. The efficiency of Pick and Drop can only be simulated by using a number of shortcut keys and/or mouse clicks for code navigation. For instance, to jump to the definition of a feature in EiffelEnvsion/Visual Studio .NET you can use the url*Eiffel editor context menu and select Go To Defintion, or press the F12 shortcut key. The url*Eiffel editor default color scheme for syntax hightlighting is true to EiffelStudio's default color scheme. This scheme may be changed, of course, using the Visual Studio .NET vxurfFontsColorsEnvironmentOptionsDialogBox 0 Fonts and Colors Options . As an indicator, every url*Eiffel editor color is prefix Eiffel.

When looking for the Cluster and Feature panes present in EiffelSudio, you need to look no futher than EiffelEnvision's url*Class View. EiffelEnvision extends the Visual Studio .NET vxoriViewingClassesTheirMembers 0 Class View to provide ancestor, decendent and caller information. For more information, see EiffelEnvision's documentation of the url*Class View.

The url*Object Browser in Visual Studio .NET is also used by EiffelEnvision to provide cluster, class and feature information. The url*Object Browser, however, extends the information provided in the url*Class View with assembly, type and method/function information for any reference's assemblies. This information is not presented in the view of the clusters, as it is in EiffelStudio. The url*References section of the url*Object Browser is used to display the vbtskAddingRemovingReferences 0 references added to an EiffelEnvision project. The information provided shows both the .NET names and Eiffel equivalents accompanied by full documentation, when available, serving both Visual Studio .NET developers and EiffelStudio developers.

Visual Studio .NET and EiffelEnvision do not provide equivalents to the Context Pane present in EiffelStudio. Some of the features present in the Class and Feature Tools are replicated, using the url*Object Browser and url*Class View. Currently, there is no Diagram Tool, Profiling or Metrics Tools in EiffelEnvision or Visual Studio .NET, although many thrid-party profiling tools are available for free via download.

The Visual Studio .NET environment introduces a concept known as a vxconVisualStudioSolutionsProjects 0 Solution . With vxconVisualStudioSolutionsProjects 0 Solution s, EiffelEnvision permits editing of multiple projects in the same Visual Studio .NET session.

EiffelEnvision also supports mulitple url*configurations for any given EiffelEnvision project. This means you can configure a single project to compile differently given a select vxconBuildConfigurations 0 build configuration . EiffelEnvision will store the project and all of its configurations in a single file so there is no need to create and maintain multiple projects for different configuration aspects.

EiffelEnvision replies on the url*precompiled library reuse mechanism much more than most EiffelStudio developers are accustomed to doing. At install time a number of url*precompiled libraries are created for use with EiffelEnvision. Their use within EiffelEnvision is to make compilation faster and deployment simpler. Using url*precompiled libraries is entirely optional and will not affect EiffelEnvision in one way or another if you decided not to use them.
Note: Precompiled libraries dramatically decrease initial compilation (Build) and recompilation (Rebuild) times.

Compilation, refered to as url*Building is much more feature saturated than in EiffelStudio. Base on a url*project's configuration, a compilation can be tweaked to provide faster compilation, the unmanaged part of the compilation may be suppressed, projects can be registered for vbconCOMInteropInVisualBasicVisualC 0 COM interop and the compilation output will be placed in a much more convenient url*project bin folder after a build has been completed.

For EiffelStudio developers, the _asug_How_Do_I_Topics3a_Debugging 0 Visual Studio .NET debugger may, at first, seem foreign as a concept. EiffelEnvision plugs into the Visual Studio .NET debugger to provide clear debugging information and a way to url*evaluate expressions. A review of the _asug_How_Do_I_Topics3a_Debugging 0 Visual Studio .NET debugger and its UI is strongly recommended, as too is reviewing the url*EiffelEnvision debugger extensions.
EiffelEnvision provides many more facilities to EiffelStudio developers, such as integrated DALGProjects 0 Deployment Projects and veoriSourceCodeControlServices 0 Source Code Control .
